Body: I've always imagined (without much evidence) that this was a two-step process. First /u:/ became /ju:/, then the /j/ modified the consonant before it, i.e. d in duke and T in Tuesday. There is some evidence, at least, that the introduction of /j/ is a recent phenomenon. Guy Deutscher (in The Unfolding of Language, page 52) quotes Charles Eastlake in 1902 saying that those born around 1800 said "Dook" for Duke and "Toosday" for Tuesday; to me this implies that they were using /u:/ and not /ju:/.
